Students are expected to develop understanding of the relationship between sound and vibrating materials as well as between the availability of light and ability to see objects. The idea that light travels from place to place can be understood by students at this level through determining the effect of placing objects made with different materials in the path of a beam of light. What are the different kinds of land and bodies of water ? How are materials similar and different from one another
column54: and how do the properties of the material s relate to their use?  What do plants need to grow?  How many types of living things live in a place ?‚Äù Second grade performance expectations include PS1
column55: LS2
column58: ESS2
column59: and ETS1 Disciplinary Core Ideas from the NRC Framework . Students are expected to develop an understanding of what plants need to grow and how plants depend on animals for seed dispersal and pollination. Students are also expected to compare the diversity of life in different habitats . An understanding of observ able properties of materials is developed by students at this level through analysis and classification of different materials. Students are able to apply their understanding of the idea that wind a nd water can change the shape of the land to compare desig n solutions to slow or prevent such change.   Students are able to use  information and model s to identify and represent the shapes and kinds of land and bodies of water in an area  and where water is found on Earth . The crosscutting concepts of patterns; cau se and effect; energy and matter ; structure and function; stability and change; and influence of engineering

All rights reserved. 21 of 103 Third Grade The performance expectations in third grade help students formulate answers to questions such as: ‚ÄúWhat is typical weather in  different parts of the world and during different times of the year? How can the impact of weather-related hazards be reduced? How do organisms vary in their traits? How are plants
column117: and environments of the past similar or different from current plants
column119: and environments? What happens to organisms when their environment changes? How do equal and unequal forces on an object affect the object? How can magnets be used?‚Äù Third grade performance expectations include PS2
column125: and ESS3 Disciplinary Core Ideas from the NRC Framework . Students are able to organize and use data to describe typical weather conditions expected during a particular season. By applying their understanding of weather-related hazards
column126: students are able to make a claim about the merit of a design solution that reduces the impacts of such hazards. Students are expected to develop an understanding of the s imilarities and differences of organisms‚Äô life cycles. An understanding that organisms have different inherited traits
column127: and that the environment can also affect the traits that an organism develops
column128: is acquired by students at this level. In addition
column129: students are able to construct an explanation using evidence for how the variations in characteristics among individuals of the same species may provide advantages in surviving
column131: and reproducing. Students are expected to develop an understanding of types of organisms that lived long ago and also about the nature of their environments. Third graders are expected to develop an understanding of the idea that when the environment changes some organisms survive and reproduce
column133: some move into the transformed environment
column134: and some die. Students are able to determine the effects of balanced and unbalanced forces on the motion of an object and the cause and effect relationships of electric or magnetic interactions between two objects not in contact with each other. They are then able to apply their understanding of magnetic interactions to define a simple design problem that can be solved with magnets. The crosscutting concepts of patterns; cause and effect; scale
column136: and quantity; systems and system models; interdependence of science
column138: and technology; and influence of engineering
column140: and science on society and the natural world are called out as organizing concepts for these disciplinary core ideas. In the third grade performance expectations
column141: students are expected to demonstrate grade-appropriate proficiency in asking questions and defining problems; developing and using models
column148: and communicating information. Students are expected to use these practices to demonstrate understanding of the core ideas. September 2017 ¬©2013 Achieve

(5-LS2-1) Disciplinary Core Ideas LS2.A:  Interdependent Relationships in Ecosystems ÔÇß The food of almost any kind of animal can be traced back to plants. Organisms are related in food webs in which some animals eat plants for food and other animals eat the animals that eat plants . Some organisms
column12: such as fungi and bacteria
column13: break down dead organisms (both plants or plants parts and animals) and therefore operate as ‚Äúdecomposers.‚Äù Decomposition eventually restores (recycles) some materials back to the soil. Organisms can survive on ly in environments in which their particular needs a re met. A healthy ecosystem is one in which multiple species of different types are each able to meet their needs in a relatively stable web of life. Newly introduced species can damage the balance of an ecosystem. ( 5-LS2-1) LS2.B:  Cycles of Matter and Energy Transfer in Ecosystems ÔÇß Matter cycles between the air and soil and among plants

column118: and Core Ideas.  Integrated and reprinted with permission from the National Academy of Sciences. 3-5-ETS1      Engineering Design Students  who demonstrate  understanding can: 3-5-ETS1 -1. Define a simple design problem reflecting a need or a want that includes specified criteria for success and constraints on materials
column120: or cost. 3-5-ETS1 -2. Generate and compare multiple possible solutions to a problem based on how well each is likely to meet the criteria and constraints of the problem. 3-5-ETS1 -3. Plan and carry out  fair tests in which variables are controlled and failure points are considered to identify aspects of a model or prototype that can be improved. The performance expectations above were developed using the following elements from the NRC document  A Framew ork for K -12 Science Education : Science and Engineering Practice s Asking Questions and Defining P roblems Asking questions and defining problems in 3‚Äì5 builds on grades K ‚Äì2 experiences and progresses to specifying qualitative relationships . ÔÇß Define a simple design problem that can be solved through the development of an object
column123: or system  and includes several criteria for success and constraints on materia ls
column125: or cost. (3 -5-ETS1-1) Planning and Carrying Out Investigations Planning and carrying out investigations to answer questions or test solutions to problems in 3 ‚Äì5 builds on K ‚Äì2 experiences and progresses to include investigations that control variables and provide evidence to support explanations or design solutions. ÔÇß Plan and conduct an investigation collaboratively to produce data to serve as the basis for evidence
column126: using fair tests in which variables are controlled and the number of trials considered.  (3-5-ETS1-3) Constructing Explanations and Designing Solutions Constructing explanations and designing solutions in 3 ‚Äì5 builds on K‚Äì2 experiences and progresses to the use of evidence in constructing explanations that specify variables that describe and predict phenomena and in designing multiple solutions to design pro blems. ÔÇß Generate and compare multiple solutions to a problem based on how well they meet the criteria and constraints of the  design  problem. (3 -5-ETS1-2) Disciplinary Core Ideas ETS1.A:  Defining and Delimiting Engineering Problems ÔÇß Possible solutions to a  problem are limited by available materials and resources (constraints). The success of a designed solution is determined by considering the desired features of a solution (criteria). Different proposals for solutions can be compared on the basis of how we ll each one meets the specified criteria for success or how well each takes the constraints into account. (3 -5-ETS1-1) ETS1.B:  Developing Possible Solutions ÔÇß Research on a problem should be carried out  before beginning to design a solution.  Testing a solu tion involves investigating how well it performs under a range of likely conditions. (3-5-ETS1-2) ÔÇß At whatever stage
column127: communicating with peers about proposed solutions is an important part of the design process

The middle school performance expectations in  the Physical Science s build on the K ‚Äì 5 ideas and capabilities  to allow learners to explain phenomena central to the physical science s but also to the life sciences and earth and space science. The performance expectations in physical science blend the core ideas with scientific and engineering practices and crosscuttin g concepts to support students in developing useable knowledge to explain real world phenomena in the physical
column158: and earth and space sciences . In the physical science s
column159: performance expectations at the middle school level focus on students develo ping understanding of several scientific practices. These include developing and using models
column163: and constructing explanations; and to use  these practices to demonstrate understanding of the core ideas. Students are also expected to demonstrate understanding of several of engineering practices including design and evaluation. The performance expectations in PS1: Matter and its Interactions  help students to formulate an answer to the question
column164: ‚ÄúHow do atomic and molecular interactions explain the properties of matter that we see and feel? ‚Äù by building understanding of what occurs at the atomic and molecular scale.  In middle school
column165: the PS1 Disciplinary Core Idea from the NRC Framework  is broken down into two sub-ideas:   the structure and properties of matter
column166: and chemical reactions.  By the end of middle school
column167: students will be able to apply understanding that pure substances have characteristic physical and chemical properties and are made from a single type of atom or molecule. They will be able to provide molecular level accounts to explain states of matters and changes between states
column168: that chemical reactions involve regroup ing of atoms to form new substances
column169: and that atoms rearrange during chemical reactions. Students are also able to apply an understanding of the design and the process of optimization in engineering to chemical reaction systems. The crosscutting concepts o f patterns ; cause and effect ; scale
column170: proportion and quantity ; energy and matter ; structure and function ; interdependence of science

column179: and communicating information. Students use these scientific and engineering practices to demonstrate understanding of the disciplinary core ideas. column186: students will develop understanding that gravitational interactions are always attractive but that September 2017 ¬©2013 Achieve

column18: (MS-PS2-4) Disciplinary Core Ideas PS2.A:  Forces and Motion ‚ñ™ For any pair of interacting objects
column19: the force exerted by the first object on the second object is equal in strength to the force that the second object exerts on the first
column20: but in the opposite direction (Newton‚Äôs third law). (MS-PS2-1) ‚ñ™ The motion of an object is determined by the sum of the forces acting on it; if the total force on the object is not zero
column21: its motion will change. The greater the mass of the object
column22: the greater the force needed to achieve the same change in motion. For an y given object
column23: a larger force causes a larger change in motion.  (MS-PS2-2) ‚ñ™ All positions of objects and the directions of forces and motions must be described in an arbitrarily chosen reference frame and arb itrarily chosen units of size. In order to share  information with other people
column24: these choices must also be shared. (MS- PS2-2) PS2.B:  Types of Interactions ‚ñ™ Electric and magnetic (electromagnetic) forces can be attractive or repulsive
column25: and their sizes depend on the magnitudes of the charges
column26: currents
column27: or magnetic strengths involved and on the distances between the interacting objects. ( MS-PS2-3) ‚ñ™ Gravitational forces are always attractive. There is a gravitational force between any two masses
column28: but it is very small except when one or both of the objects hav e large mass ‚Äîe.g.
column29: Earth and the sun. (MS-PS2-4) ‚ñ™ Forces that act at a distance (electric
column30: magnetic
column31: and gravitational ) can be explained by fields that extend through space and can be mapped by their effect on a test object ( a charged object
column32: or  a ball
column33: respectively). ( MS-PS2-5) Crosscutting Concepts Cause and Effect ‚ñ™ Cause and effect relationships may be used to predict phenomena i n natural or designed systems. ( MS-PS2-3)
column34: (MS-PS2- 5) Systems and System Models ‚ñ™ Models can be used to represent systems and their interactions ‚Äîsuch as inputs

column46: Inc. All rights reserved. 55 of 103 Middle School Life Science Students in middle school develop understanding of key concepts to help them make sense of life science . The ideas build  upon students‚Äô science understanding from earlier grades and from the disciplinary core ideas
column48: and crosscutting concepts  of other experiences with physical and earth sciences . There are four life s cience disciplinary core ideas in middle school: 1) From Molecules to Organisms: Structures and Processes
column50: Energy
column52: 3) Heredity: Inheritance and Variation of Traits
column53: 4) Biological Evolution: Unity and Diversity . The performance expectations in middle school blend the core ideas with scientific and engineering practices and crosscutting concep ts to support students in developing useable knowledge across the science disciplines. While the performance expectations in middle school life science couple particular practices with specific disciplinary core ideas
column54: instructional decisions should includ e use of many science and engineering practices integrated in  the performance expectations. The performance expectations in LS1: From Molecules to Organisms: Structures and Processes  help students formulate an answer to the question
column55: ‚ÄúHow can one explain the ways cells contribute to the function of living organisms. ‚Äù The LS1 Disciplinary Core Idea from the NRC Framework  is organized into  four sub -ideas:  Structure and Function
column57: Organization for Mat ter and Energy Flow in Organisms
column58: and Information Processing . Students can gather information  and use this information to support explanations of the structure and function relationship of cells . They can communicate understanding of cell th eory. They have a basic understanding of the role of cells in body systems and how those systems work to support the life functions of the organism. The understanding of cells provides a contex t for the plant process of photosynthesis and the movement of matter and energ y needed for the cell. Students can construct an explanation for how environmental and genetic factors affect growth of organism s.  They can connect this to the role of animal behaviors in reproduction of animals as well as the dependence  of some plants on  animal behaviors  for the ir reproduction. Crosscutting concepts of cause and effect
column60: and matter and energy are called out as organizing concepts for  the core ideas about proces ses of living organisms. The performance expectations in LS2: Interactions
column62: and Dynamics Relationships in Ecosystems  help student s formulate an answer to the question
column63: ‚ÄúHow does a system of living and non -living things operate to meet the needs of the organisms in an ecosystem?‚Äù  The LS2 Disciplinary Core Idea is  divided into three  sub-ideas:  Interdepend ent Relationships in Ecosystems;  Cycles of Matter an d Energy Transfer in Ecosystems; and  Ecosystem Dynami cs
column65: and Resilience . Students can analyze and interpret data
column67: and construct  argument s and demonstrate  a deeper understanding of resources and the cycling of matter and the flow of energy in ecosystem s. They can also study patterns of the interactions among organisms within  an ecosystem. They consider biotic and abiotic factors in an ecosystem and the effects these factors have on po pulation. They evaluate competing design solutions for maintaining biodiversity  and ecosystem services. The performance expectations in LS3: Heredity: Inheritance and Variation of Traits  help students formulate an answer to the question
column68: ‚ÄúHow do living organism s pass traits from one generation to the next?‚Äù The LS3 Disciplinary Core Idea from the NRC Framework  includes two sub-ideas:  Inheritance of Traits
column69: and Variation of Traits.  Stude nts can use models to describe September 2017 ¬©2013 Achieve
column70: Inc. All rights reserved. 56 of 103 ways gene mutations and sexual reproduction contr ibute to genetic variation.  Crosscutting concepts of cause and effect and structure and function provide students with a de eper understanding of how gene structure determines differences in the functioning of organisms. The performance expectations in LS4: Biological Evolution: Unity and Diversity  help students formulate an answer to the questio n
column71: ‚ÄúHow do organisms  change over time in response to changes in the environment?‚Äù The LS4 Disciplinary Core Idea is divided into four sub-ideas:  Evidence of Common Ancestry and Diversity
column72: Natural Selection
column74: and Biodiversity and Humans . Students can construct expl anations based on evidence to support fundamental understand ings of natural selection and evolution. They  can use ideas of genetic variation in a population to make sense of organisms surviving and reproducin g
column75: hence passing on the traits of the species. T hey are able to use fossil records and anatomical similarities of the relationships among organisms and species  to support their understanding . Crosscutting concepts of patterns and structure and function contribute to the evidence students can use to describe biological evolution. September 2017 ¬©2013 Achieve

(MS-LS2-4) Disciplinary Core Ideas LS2.A:  Interdependent Relationships in Ecosystems ‚ñ™ Organisms
column15: are dependent on their environmental interactions both with other living things and with nonliving factors . (MS-LS2-1) ‚ñ™ In any ecosystem
column16: organisms and populations with similar requirements for food
column17: water
column19: or other resources may compete with each other for limited resources
column20: access to which consequently constrains their growth and reproduction.  (MS-LS2- 1) ‚ñ™ Growth of organisms and population increases are lim ited by access to resources.  (MS-LS2-1) ‚ñ™ Similarly
column21: predatory interactions may reduce the number of organisms or eliminate whol e populations of organisms. Mutually beneficial interactions
column22: in contrast

column24: predatory

column27: both living and nonliving
column28: are shared.  (MS-LS2-2) LS2.B:  Cycle of Matter and Energy Transfer in Ecosystems ‚ñ™ Food webs are models that demonstrate how matter and energy is transferred between producers
column29: consumers
column30: and decomposers as the three groups interact  within an ecosystem. Transfers of matter into and out of the physical environment occur at every level. Decomposers recycle nutrients from dead plant or animal matter back to the soil in terrestrial environments or to the water in aquatic environments. The atoms that make up the organisms in an ecosystem are cycled repeatedly between the living and nonliving parts of the ecosystem. ( MS-LS2-3) LS2.C:  Ecosystem Dynamics
column31: Functioning
column32: and Resilience ‚ñ™ Ecosystems are dynamic in nature; their characteristics can vary over time. Disruptions to any physical or biological component of an ecosystem can lead to  shifts in all its populations. (MS-LS2-4) ‚ñ™ Biodiversity describes the variety of species found in Ear th‚Äôs terrestrial and oceanic ecosystems. The completeness or integrity of an ecosystem‚Äôs biodiversity is often used as a measure of its health. column33: such as food

column35: and medicines
column36: as well as ecosystem services that humans rely on ‚Äîfor example
column37: water purification and recycling. The middle  school performance expectations  in Earth Space  Science build on the elementary  school ideas and skills and  allow middle  school students to explain more in -depth phenomena central  not only  to the earth and space  science s
column104: but to life and physical  science s as well .  These performance expectations blend the core ideas with scientific and engineering practices and crosscutting concepts  to support students in developing useable knowledge  to explain ideas across the science disciplines .  While the performance expectations show n in middle school earth and space  science couple particular practices with specific disciplinary core ideas
column105: instructional decisions should include use of many practices that lead to the performance expectations. The performance expectations in ESS1:  Earth‚Äôs Place in the Universe
column106: help students formulate an answer to question s such as :  ‚ÄúWhat is Earth‚Äôs place in the Universe
column107: What makes up our solar system and how can the motion of Earth explain seasons and eclipses
column108: and How do people figure out that the  Earth and life on Earth have changed through time? ‚Äù  The ESS1 Disciplinary Core Idea from the NRC Framework  is broken down into three sub-ideas: the universe and its stars
column109: Earth and the solar system and the history of planet Earth .  Students examine the Earth‚Äôs place in relation to the solar system
column111: and universe. There is a strong emphasis on a systems approach
column112: using models of the solar system  to explain astronomical and other observations of the cyclic pat terns of eclipses  and seasons.  There is also a strong connection to engineering through the instruments and technologies that have allowed us to explore the objects in our solar system and obtain the data that support the theories that explain the formation and evolution of the univers e.  Students examine geoscience data in order to understand the processes and events in Earth‚Äôs history.  The crosscutting concepts of patterns

column98: Inc. All rights reserved. 84 of 103 High S chool Life Sciences Stude nts in high school develop understanding of key concepts that will  help them make sense of life science . The ideas are buil t upon s tudents‚Äô science understanding  of disciplinary core ideas
column100: and crosscutting concepts from earlier grades. There are four life s cience disciplinary core ideas in high  school:  1) From Molecules to Organisms: Structures and Processes
column104: 3) Heredity: Inheritance and Variation of Traits
column105: 4) Biological Evolution: Unity and Diversity . The performance expectations  for high school life science blend core ideas with scientific and engineering practices and cro sscutting concepts to support students in developing useable knowledge that can be applied across the science disciplines. While the pe rformance expectations in high  school life science couple particular practices with specific disciplinary core ideas
column106: instructional decisions should include  use of many practices underlying  the performance expectations. The performance expectations in LS1: From Molecules to Organisms: Structures and Processes  help students formulate an answer  to the question
column107: ‚ÄúHow do organisms live  and grow?‚Äù  The LS1 Disciplinary Core Idea from the NRC Framework  is presented as  three sub- ideas:  Structure and Function
column109: and Organization for Matter and Energy Flow in Organisms . In these performance expectations
column110: students demonstrate that they can use investigations  and gather evidence to support explanations of cell function and reproduction. They understand the role of proteins as essential to the work of the cell and living systems. Student s can use mod els to explain  photosynthesis
column112: and the cycling of matter and flow of energy in living organisms. The cellular processes can be  used as a model for  understanding of the hierarchical  organization of organism. Crosscutting concepts of m atter and energy
column114: and systems and system models  provide student s with insights to the structures and processes  of organisms. The performance expectations in LS2: Ecosystems: Interactions
column116: and Dynamics help student s formulate an answer to the question
column117: ‚ÄúHow and why do organisms interact with their environment
column118: and what are the effects of these interactions?‚Äù  The LS2 Disciplinary Core Idea includes  four sub -ideas:  Interdependent Relationships in Ecosystems
column119: Cycles of Matter and Energy Transfer in Ecosystems
column123: and Social Interactions and Group Behavior. High school students can use mathematical reasoning to demonstrate  understanding of fundamental concepts of carrying capacity
column125: and the cycling of matter and flow of energy among organisms in an ecosystem.  These mathematical models provide support of students‚Äô  conceptual understanding of systems and their ability to  develop  design solutions for reducing the impact of human activities on the environment and maintaining biodiversity . Crosscutting concepts of systems and system models play a  central role in students‚Äô understanding of science and engineering practices and core i deas of ecosystems. The performance expectations in LS3: Heredity: Inheritance and Variation of Traits  help students formulate answer s to the question s:  ‚ÄúHow are characteristics of one generation passed to the next ? How can individuals of the same species and even siblings have different characteristics?‚Äù The LS3 Disciplinary Core Idea from the NRC Framework  includes two sub- ideas:  Inheritance of Traits
column126: and Variation of Traits.  Students are able to ask questions
column128: and use concepts of probab ility to explain the genetic variation in a September 2017 ¬©2013 Achieve
column129: Inc. All rights reserved. 85 of 103 population. Students demonstrate understanding of w hy individuals of the same species vary in how they look
column131: and behave. Students can explain the mechanisms of genetic inheritance and describe the environmental and genetic causes of gene mutation and the alteration of gene expression.   Crosscutting concepts of patterns and cause and effect are called out as organizing concepts for these core ideas. The performance expectations in LS4: Biological Evolution: Unity and Diversity  help students formulate an answer to the question
column132: ‚ÄúWhat evidence shows that different species are related? The LS4 Disciplinary Core Idea involves four sub -ideas:  Evidence o f Common Ancestry and Diversity
column135: and Biodiversity and Humans. Students  can construct explanations for the processes of natural select ion and evolution and communicate how multi ple lines of evidence support  these explanations. Students can evaluate evidence of the condition s that may result in new species and understand the role of genetic variation in natural selection .   Additionally
column136: students  can apply concepts of probability to explain trends in populati ons as those trends  relate to a dvantageous heritable traits in a specific  environment. The crosscutting concepts of cause and effect and systems and system models  play an important rol e in students ‚Äô understanding of the evolution of life on Earth. September 2017 ¬©2013 Achieve

column22: which are limits to the numbers of organisms and populations they can support. These limits result from such factors as the availability of living and nonliving resources and from such challenges such as predation
column23: competition
column24: and disease. Organisms would have the capacity to produce populations of great size were it not for the fact that environments and r esources are finite. This fundamental tension affects the abundance (number of individuals) of species in any given ecosystem. ( HS-LS2-1)
column25: (HS- LS2-2) LS2.B:  Cycles of Matter and Energy Transfer in Ecosystems ÔÇßPhotosynthesis and cellular respiration (including anaerobic processes) provide most of the energy for life processes. column26: only a small fraction of the matter consumed at the lower level is transferred upward
column27: to produce growth and release energy in cellular respiration at the higher level. Given this inefficiency
column28: there are generally fewer organisms at higher levels of a food web. Some  matter reacts to release energy for life functions
column29: some matter is stored in newly made structures
column30: and much is discarded. The chemical elements that make up the molecules of organisms pass through food webs and into and o ut of the atmosphere and soil
column31: and they are combined and recombined in different ways. At each link in an ecosystem

column10: and student -generated evidence. (HS -LS3-2)Disciplinary Core Ideas LS1.A:  Structure and Function ÔÇßAll cells contain genetic information in the form of DNA molecules. Genes are regions in the DNA that contain the instructions that code for the formation of proteins . (secondary to HS -LS3-1) (Note: This Disciplinary Core Idea is also addressed by HS -LS1-1.) LS3.A:  Inheritance of Traits ÔÇßEach chromosome consists of a single very long DNA molecule
column11: and each gene on the chromosome is a particular segment of that DNA. The instructions for forming species‚Äô characteristics are carried in DNA. All cells in an organism have the same genetic conte nt
column12: but the genes used (expressed) by the cell may be regulated in different ways. Not all DNA codes for a protein; some segments of DNA are involved in regulatory or structural functions
column13: and some have no as-yet known function. (HS-LS3-1) LS3.B:  Variation of Traits ÔÇßIn sexual reproduction
column14: chromosomes can sometimes swap sections during the process of meiosis (cell division)
column15: thereby creating new genetic combinations and thus  more genetic variation. Although  DNA replication  is tightly  regulated  and remarkably  accurate
column16: errors  do occur  and result  in mutations
column17: which  are also a source  of genetic  variation.  Environmental factors can also cause mutations in genes
column18: and viable mutations are inherited. ( HS-LS3-2) ÔÇßEnvironmental  factors  also  affect  expression  of traits
column19: and hence  affect  the probability of occurrences of traits in a population. Thus the variation and distribution of traits observed depends on both genetic and environmental factors. ( HS-LS3-2)

column23: and Quantity ÔÇßAlgebraic thinking is used to examine scientific data and predict the effect of a change in one variable on another (e.g.

The high school performance expectations  in Earth and Space  Science build on the middle school ideas and skills and  allow high school students  to explain more in -depth phenomena central  not only  to the earth  and space  science s
column142: but to life and physical  science s as well .  These performance expectations blend the core ideas with scientif ic and engineering practices and crosscutting concepts  to support students in developing useable knowledge  to explain ideas across the science disciplines .  While the performance expectations shown in high school earth and space  science couple particular practices with specific disciplinary core ideas
column143: instructional decisions should include use of many practices that lead to the performance expectations. The performance expectations in ESS1:  Earth‚Äôs Place in the Universe
column144: help students formulate an answer to the question:  ‚ÄúWhat is the universe
column145: and what is Earth‚Äôs place in it? ‚Äù The ESS1 Disciplinary Core Idea from the NRC Framework  is broken down into three sub-ideas: the universe and its stars
column146: Earth and the solar system and the history of planet Earth.  Students examine the processes governing the formation
column148: and workings of the solar system and universe. Some concepts studied are fundamental to science
column149: such as understanding how the matter of our world formed during the Big Bang and within the cores of stars. Others concepts are practical
column150: such as understanding how short -term changes in the behavior of our sun directly affect humans. Engineering and technology play a large role here in obtaining and analyzing the data that support the theories of the formation of the solar system and universe. The crosscutting concepts of patterns
column155: and stability and change  are called out as organizing concepts for these disciplinar y core ideas .  In the ESS1 performance expectations
column156: students are expected to demonstrate proficiency in developing and using models
column161: evaluating and communicating information; and to use these practices to demonstrate understanding of the core ideas. The performance expectations in ESS2:  Earth‚Äôs Systems
column162: help students formulate an answer to the question:  ‚ÄúHow and why is  Earth constantly changing?‚Äù  The ESS2 Disciplinary Core Idea from the NRC Framework  is broken down into five sub-ideas: Earth materials and systems
column163: plate tectonics and large -scale system interactions
column164: the roles of water in Earth‚Äôs surface processes
column166: and bioge ology .  For the purpose of the NGSS
column167: biogeology has been addressed within the life science standards.  Students develop models and explanations for the ways that feedbacks between different Earth systems control the appearance of Earth‚Äôs surface. Central to this is the tension between internal systems
column168: which are largely responsible for creating land at Earth‚Äôs surface
column169: and the sun -driven surface systems that tear down the land through weathering and erosion. Students begin to examine the ways that human activities cause feedbacks that create changes to other systems.  Students understand the system interactions that control weather and climate
column170: with a major emphasis on the mechanisms and implications of climate change. Students model the flow of energy between different components of the weather system and how this affects chemical cycles such as the carbon cycle. The crosscutting concepts of cause and effect
column172: structure and function and stability and change are called out as organizing concepts for these disci plinary core ideas. In the ESS2 performance expectations
column173: students are expected to demonstrate proficiency in September 2017 ¬©2013 Achieve

column180: and global climate change.  Students understand the complex and significant interdependencies between humans and the rest of Earth‚Äôs systems through the impacts of natural hazards
column182: and the significant environmental impacts of human activities. Engineering and technology figure prominently here
column183: as students use mathematical thinking and the analysis of geoscience data to examine and construct solutions to the many challenges facing long -term human sustainability on Earth .  The crosscutting concepts of cause and effect
